H0.text: During a space mission, astronauts perform the experiment to obtain data to test a hypothesis, even though scientists have predicted the outcome.

H1.text: To make a complete observation, astronauts perform the experiment in space even though scientists have already predicted the outcome.

H2.text: To make a report of the procedures, astronauts conduct experiments during a space mission even though scientists have already predicted the outcomes.

H3.text: To make a hypothesis understandable is why astronauts perform the experiment in space, even when scientists have already predicted its outcome, allowing them to confirm the prediction and communicate it clearly.

A4.text: If the outcome is already known, it is called a consequence and should have already been considered while formulating the hypothesis.

A5.text: Scientific inquiry generally aims to obtain knowledge in the form of testable explanations that scientists can use to predict the results of future experiments.

A6.text: The conclusion of the test is only as solid as the sample upon which it is based.

A7.text: Statistically significant findings are often misleading in psychology.
